section.title: Overview
section.para: The Grizzly 2.0 HTTP framework provides codecs for marshalling/unmarshalling HTTP request/response data for both the server and clients. In addition to the codecs themselves, the framework includes base HTTP primitives and utilities to make working with the protocol simpler.

section.title: Components of the Framework
section.para: There are many components that provide the HTTP protocol handling within Grizzly. This section will cover the major components.

section.title: HttpCodecFilter (Server/Client)
section.para: The HttpCodecFilter is the base Filter that provides the ability to marshall/unmarshall HTTP primitives to and from the network. Note that this class does a majority of the heavy lifting when dealing with the HTTP protocol. However, Grizzly does have two subclasses of HttpCodecFilter to deal with different semantics depending on which side of the connection being dealt with.

section.title: HTTP Messages
section.para: In order to make working with HTTP easier for the developer, Grizzly abstracts the network representation of an http protocol request/response into various different message objects.
As seen from the diagram all messages produced/consumed by the HttpCodecFilter are simply HttpPackets. From there, there are several specialized packet representations:

row.entry: HttpHeaders represents the http message headers.
Represents the entity body of a http message.
This is a specialized form of HttpContent. It's only used when the chunked transfer encoding is used and represents the length of the current chunk.
A form of HttpHeader representing a HTTP request.
A form of HttpHeader representing a HTTP response to a HTTP request.

section.para: HttpRequestPacket, HttpResponsePacket, HttpContent, and HttpTrailer (if using the chunked transfer encoding) all have Builder objects in order to create new instances. For example, in order to create a response for a particular request:
section.programlisting: final HttpResponsePacket.Builder builder = response.builder(request); final HttpResponsePacket response = builder.chunked(true).status(200).reasonPhrase("OK").build();

section.title: Transfer Encodings
section.para: Transfer encodings allow special transformation formats for communciating http messages between client and server. Grizzly includes two transfer encoding implementations:

row.entry: Implemented by org.glassfish.grizzly.http.FixedLengthTransferEncoding. This transfer-encoing will be used when content-length has been specified, or if chunking has been disabled. In the case where chunking is disabled and no content length has been specified, the implementation will try to determine the content length on its own.

Implemented by org.glassfish.grizzly.ChunkedTransferEncoding. This transfer-encoding will be used when specified on a request or response. For more details on the chunked transfer-encoding, see: http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec3.html#sec3.6.1.

section.para: Custom transfer-encoding implementations may be provided by implementing the TransferEncoding interface:
Custom TransferEncoding implementations may be registered by calling HttpCodecFilter.addTransferEncoding().

section.title: Content Encodings
section.para: Content encodings describe when encodings have been applied to the message body prior to their being transfered to the recipient. At the time that this was written, Grizzly 2.0 only supports gzip content encoding (implemented by org.glassfish.grizzly.http.GzipContentEnconding).
Custom content-encodings can be provided by implementing the ContentEncoding interface:
Custom ContentEncoding implementations may be registered by calling HttpCodecFilter.addContentEncoding().

row.entry: Represents a HTTP cookie. Supports version 0 and version 1 cookies.
A Builder implementation for created a List of Cookies from the message headers of a HttpHeader packet. This can be used on either the server or client side.
A wrapper for Cookie that delays parsing the header value into the values exposed by Cookie until needed.
Represents a portion of a buffer and exposes various operations to operate on said portion.
A utility class for dealing with character arrays in an efficent manner.
Represents a chunk of data that may be a BufferChunk, CharChunk, or String.
